projects.title: The acquisition of temporal relations in a second language (L2)
projects.description:
• Field: syntax and semantics of tense and aspect, sequence of tense, grammatical/viewpoint aspect, second language (L2) acquisition, applied linguistics, quantitative research

• Description: The present project investigates the acquisition of simple and complex temporal relations in a second language (L2), focusing on the role of grammatical or viewpoint aspect. This concerns the aspectual difference between (a) ‘John ate an apple’ and (b) ‘John was eating an apple’ (for simple temporal relations), and between (c) ‘Mary said that John ate an apple’ and (d) ‘Mary said that John was eating an apple’ (for complex ones). While previous L2 research has extensively focused on the acquisition of grammatical aspect and simple temporal relations, there is little research to date on complex orderings. In this project, it is examined to what extent L2 knowledge of grammatical aspect for simple temporal relations predicts knowledge for complex ones within the same group of language learners, and to what extent this is modulated by language proficiency. The outcome of the present project will inform modern theories of L2 acquisition and grammatical aspect.

contributors.headline: Doctoral Researcher | Digging into data on language learning | Applied Linguistics | Second Language (L2) Acquisition | Experimental Design | Online Surveys | Data Analysis | R Programming

projects.title: Are all misspellings equally noticeable? Towards a unified theory of (ortho-)graphic and phonological factors for the visual prominence of misspellings
projects.description:
• Field: reading, attention, psycholinguistics, quantitative research

• Description: Where do we focus our attention while reading? What do we notice? What do we miss? In the present project, we investigated how misspelt words influence where people’s attention is drawn to during reading. Specifically, it was asked to what extent orthographic and phonological factors, such as the position within a word and the distance from the stressed syllable, affect the detection of spelling errors. We predicted an interplay between orthography and phonology such that the misspelling’s noticeability increases or decreases within different ‘ortho-phonological’ contexts. This hypothesis was tested in two experiments involving a misspelling recognition task in German, for which we collected native speakers’ data relevant to performance accuracy, reaction times, and eye movements. The results appear to support our predictions and contribute to existing research concerning reading and attention.

projects.title: Evaluating the GOBL CALL system: Users’ self-perceptions and attitudes
projects.description:
• Field: computer-assisted language learning (CALL), serious gaming, second language (L2) learning, language and speech technology, applied linguistics, quantitative research

• Description: The European Lifelong Learning Programme project ‘Games Online for Basic Language learning’ (GOBL) aimed to provide access to materials for the development of communicative proficiency in Dutch, French, and English through web-based mini-games. These mini-games and their respective language versions were tested in four countries: The Netherlands (Dutch), Belgium (French), United Kingdom and South Africa (English). Four types of mini-games were developed, and in two of them users could use Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) to support spoken interaction. The evaluation phase of the GOBL project represented a crucial stage for the future improvement of its four mini-games with computer-assisted language learning (CALL) purposes. The goal was to identify trends in the user’ perceptions and attitudes towards (aspects of) the mini-games’ final version, including any differences in the users’ experience linked to (a) the two versions of the mini-games (with and without ASR), (b) the languages used across the aforementioned countries, and (c) the users’ linguistic and gaming proficiency levels.

profile_positions.description:
• International double-degree PhD project in Applied Linguistics (University of Greenwich, UK) and in Linguistics (University of Groningen, NL): ‘The Acquisition of Temporal Relations in a Second Language (L2)’
• Designing, implementing, and running novel behavioural experiments, language proficiency tests, and surveys via Qualtrics
• Recruiting participants (Dutch natives, Spanish natives, and English natives learning L2 Spanish) and collecting data via Prolific
• Cleaning, exploring, analysing, and visualising experimental and survey data using R: hypothesis testing, correlations, linear regression, logistic regression, linear mixed-effects models
• Reporting results in written (PhD dissertation, peer-reviewed journal articles, and conference proceedings papers) and oral form (presentations at 2 international conferences addressed to technical and non-technical audience)
• Managing a long-term (4+ years) research project in coordination with a 10-people team (4 supervisors, 4 interns/student assistants, 2 external volunteers)
• Managing research and travel budgets
• Networking with peers and colleagues at international conferences and events
• Attending 6 summer/winter schools and 40+ training courses/modules on topics ranging from research methods to data science and data management, research communication and dissemination, academic writing and publishing, teaching, professional conduct, self- and project management, professional and personal development

profile_positions.description:

• Running eye-tracking and electroencephalography (EEG) experiments investigating human (spoken) language processing, attention allocation, and human-computer interaction using the visual world paradigm
